title: 115_hr6221
content: The Act may be cited as the "Carson City Mint 150th Anniversary Commemorative Coin Act of 2018". The Congress established the Carson City Mint in 1863 to meet coinage needs during the silver rush in Nevada. Designed by Alfred Mullett, the mint opened in December 1869 after delays caused by the Civil War. Coins were struck there starting February 11, 1870. The Carson City Mint, with the "CC" mint mark, coined over $49,000,000 of silver and gold before ending production in 1893 due to reduced mining. It is now listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The Carson City Mint, known for its "CC" mint mark, produced over $49,000,000 of silver and gold before closing in 1893 due to decreased mining activity. It is currently listed on the National Register of Historic Places. SEC. 3 outlines coin specifications. In commemoration of the Carson City Mint's 150th Anniversary, the Secretary of the Treasury will mint $5 gold coins and $1 silver coins with specific weights, diameters, and compositions. These coins will be legal tender. All coins minted under this Act for the Carson City Mint's 150th Anniversary shall be considered numismatic items. The design of coins minted for the Carson City Mint's 150th Anniversary shall symbolize the mint building's significance to Nevada and the nation's history. Each coin will feature the coin's value, the year "2020", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the Nevada State Museum Dedicated Trust Fund and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee to ensure timely minting. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities during a 1-year period starting on January 1, 2020. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins shall be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will receive a reasonable discount. All sales of coins minted under this Act include a surcharge: $35 per $5 coin and $10 per $1 coin. Surcharges received will be paid to the Nevada State Museum Dedicated Trust Fund to support its mission. The fund will be audited as per the requirements of the law. No surcharge may be included for any coin issuance in a calendar year if the conditions are not met. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue guidance to limit the number of commemorative coin programs issued in a calendar year to comply with the annual issuance limitation under title 31, United States Code. SEC. 8. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure that minting coins will not cost the government and no funds are disbursed until all costs are recovered by the Treasury.
